vision_json.prompt_sent:
Extract ONLY publication metadata from these academic paper pages.

CRITICAL: This data will be sent to 11 external APIs, so format accuracy is essential.

FIELD REQUIREMENTS WITH EXACT FORMATS:

1. **Title**: Clean title for API queries (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
   - Remove line breaks, extra spaces, formatting
   - No HTML tags or special characters  
   - Example: "Effects of Machine Learning on Healthcare Outcomes"

2. **Authors**: API-compatible author list (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
   - Each author as separate string in array
   - Format: "FirstName LastName" or "F. LastName"
   - Clean, no extra punctuation
   - Example: ["John Smith", "M. Johnson", "Sarah Williams"]

3. **DOI**: Standard DOI format for resolution APIs
   - Must start with "10." if present
   - Clean format without URL prefixes
   - Example: "10.1234/journal.2024.001"

4. **Journal**: Clean journal name for database queries
   - Full journal name preferred over abbreviations
   - Remove extra formatting, parentheses
   - Example: "Nature Medicine"

5. **Year**: Numeric format for date filtering
   - 4-digit NUMBER only (not string)
   - Example: 2024

6. **Volume**: Clean number for bibliographic APIs
   - Numbers only, no "Vol." prefix
   - Example: "15"

7. **Issue**: Clean number format
   - Numbers only, no "No." or "Issue" prefix
   - Example: "3"

8. **Pages**: Standard page range for citations
   - Format: "start-end" or single page
   - Example: "123-135" or "45"

9. **PMID**: PubMed ID for medical APIs
   - Numbers only, no "PMID:" prefix
   - Example: "12345678"

10. **PMCID**: PubMed Central ID for open access papers
    - Numbers only, no "PMC" prefix
    - Often appears near PMID in biomedical papers
    - Example: "9876543"

11. **Keywords**: API-compatible keyword list
    - Each keyword as separate string
    - Research-quality terms, no punctuation
    - Example: ["machine learning", "healthcare", "clinical outcomes"]

11. **Abstract**: Complete clean text (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
    - Remove formatting, line breaks, extra spaces
    - Complete sentences, proper punctuation
    - Search thoroughly across ALL pages
    - This is CRITICAL for Semantic Scholar and other APIs

12. **Publisher**: Clean organization name
    - Official publisher name
    - Example: "Elsevier" or "Nature Publishing Group"

ABSTRACT EXTRACTION PRIORITY:
- Look thoroughly across ALL pages for abstract sections
- Extract COMPLETE text, including multiple paragraphs
- Check: Abstract, Summary, Introduction summary paragraphs
- This field is CRITICAL for API enrichment success

Return JSON format:
{
  "Title": "clean title without formatting",
  "Authors": ["Author One", "Author Two"],
  "DOI": "10.xxxx/xxxxx",
  "Journal": "clean journal name", 
  "Year": 2024,
  "Volume": "15",
  "Issue": "3", 
  "Pages": "123-135",
  "Abstract": "complete clean abstract text",
  "Keywords": ["keyword1", "keyword2"],
  "PMID": "12345678",
  "PMCID": "9876543",
  "Publisher": "publisher name"
}

Return null for fields not clearly visible. The Abstract field is MOST IMPORTANT for downstream API success.

extracted_data.Title: Extended reality used in the treatment of phantom limb pain: a multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial
extracted_data.Abstract: Phantom limb pain (PLP) represents a significant challenge after amputation. This study investigated the use of phantom motor execution (PME) and phantom motor imagery (PMI) facilitated by extended reality (XR) for the treatment of PLP. Both treatments used XR, but PME involved overt execution of phantom movements, relying on the decoding of motor intent using machine learning to enable real-time control in XR. In contrast, PMI involved mental rehearsal of phantom movements guided by XR. The study hypothesized that PME would be superior to PMI. A multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial was conducted in 9 outpatient clinics across 7 countries. Eighty-one participants with PLP were randomly assigned to PME or PMI training. The primary outcome was the change in PLP, measured by the Pain Rating Index, from baseline to treatment cessation. Secondary outcomes included various aspects related to PLP, such as the rate of clinically meaningful reduction in pain (CMRP; >50% pain decrease). No evidence was found for superiority of overt execution (PME) over imagery (PMI) using XR. PLP decreased by 64.5% and 68.2% in PME and PMI groups, respectively. Thirty-seven PME participants (71%) and 19 PMI participants (68%) experienced CMRP. Positive changes were recorded in all other secondary outcome differences. Pain reduction for PME was larger than previously reported. Despite our initial hypothesis not being supported, PME and PMI, aided by XR, are likely to offer meaningful PLP relief to most users. These findings merit consideration for clinical implementation.

source-name.value: Web of Science Researcher Profile Sync

AbstractText: Phantom limb pain (PLP) represents a significant challenge after amputation. This study investigated the use of phantom motor execution (PME) and phantom motor imagery (PMI) facilitated by extended reality (XR) for the treatment of PLP. Both treatments used XR, but PME involved overt execution of phantom movements, relying on the decoding of motor intent using machine learning to enable real-time control in XR. In contrast, PMI involved mental rehearsal of phantom movements guided by XR. The study hypothesized that PME would be superior to PMI. A multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial was conducted in 9 outpatient clinics across 7 countries. Eighty-one participants with PLP were randomly assigned to PME or PMI training. The primary outcome was the change in PLP, measured by the Pain Rating Index, from baseline to treatment cessation. Secondary outcomes included various aspects related to PLP, such as the rate of clinically meaningful reduction in pain (CMRP; >50% pain decrease). No evidence was found for superiority of overt execution (PME) over imagery (PMI) using XR. PLP decreased by 64.5% and 68.2% in PME and PMI groups, respectively. Thirty-seven PME participants (71%) and 19 PMI participants (68%) experienced CMRP. Positive changes were recorded in all other outcomes, without group differences. Pain reduction for PME was larger than previously reported. Despite our initial hypothesis not being confirmed, PME and PMI, aided by XR, are likely to offer meaningful PLP relief to most patients. These findings merit consideration of these therapies as viable treatment options and alternatives to pharmacological treatments.

message.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
          <jats:p>Phantom limb pain (PLP) represents a significant challenge after amputation. This study investigated the use of phantom motor execution (PME) and phantom motor imagery (PMI) facilitated by extended reality (XR) for the treatment of PLP. Both treatments used XR, but PME involved overt execution of phantom movements, relying on the decoding of motor intent using machine learning to enable real-time control in XR. In contrast, PMI involved mental rehearsal of phantom movements guided by XR. The study hypothesized that PME would be superior to PMI. A multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial was conducted in 9 outpatient clinics across 7 countries. Eighty-one participants with PLP were randomly assigned to PME or PMI training. The primary outcome was the change in PLP, measured by the Pain Rating Index, from baseline to treatment cessation. Secondary outcomes included various aspects related to PLP, such as the rate of clinically meaningful reduction in pain (CMRP; >50% pain decrease). No evidence was found for superiority of overt execution (PME) over imagery (PMI) using XR. PLP decreased by 64.5% and 68.2% in PME and PMI groups, respectively. Thirty-seven PME participants (71%) and 19 PMI participants (68%) experienced CMRP. Positive changes were recorded in all other outcomes, without group differences. Pain reduction for PME was larger than previously reported. Despite our initial hypothesis not being confirmed, PME and PMI, aided by XR, are likely to offer meaningful PLP relief to most patients. These findings merit consideration of these therapies as viable treatment options and alternatives to pharmacological treatments.</jats:p>

data.affiliation: Department of Electrical Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, Goteborg, Sweden.
data.abstractText:
Abstract

Phantom limb pain (PLP) represents a significant challenge after amputation. This study investigated the use of phantom motor execution (PME) and phantom motor imagery (PMI) facilitated by extended reality (XR) for the treatment of PLP. Both treatments used XR, but PME involved overt execution of phantom movements, relying on the decoding of motor intent using machine learning to enable real-time control in XR. In contrast, PMI involved mental rehearsal of phantom movements guided by XR. The study hypothesized that PME would be superior to PMI. A multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial was conducted in 9 outpatient clinics across 7 countries. Eighty-one participants with PLP were randomly assigned to PME or PMI training. The primary outcome was the change in PLP, measured by the Pain Rating Index, from baseline to treatment cessation. Secondary outcomes included various aspects related to PLP, such as the rate of clinically meaningful reduction in pain (CMRP; >50% pain decrease). No evidence was found for superiority of overt execution (PME) over imagery (PMI) using XR. PLP decreased by 64.5% and 68.2% in PME and PMI groups, respectively. Thirty-seven PME participants (71%) and 19 PMI participants (68%) experienced CMRP. Positive changes were recorded in all other outcomes, without group differences. Pain reduction for PME was larger than previously reported. Despite our initial hypothesis not being confirmed, PME and PMI, aided by XR, are likely to offer meaningful PLP relief to most patients. These findings merit consideration of these therapies as viable treatment options and alternatives to pharmacological treatments.
data.authorString: Lendaro E, Van der Sluis CK, Hermansson L, Bunketorp-Käll L, Burger H, Keesom E, Widehammar C, Munoz-Novoa M, McGuire BE, O'Reilly P, Earley EJ, Iqbal S, Kristoffersen MB, Stockselius A, Gudmundson L, Hill W, Diers M, Turner KL, Weiss T, Ortiz-Catalan M.

data.title: Extended reality used in the treatment of phantom limb pain: a multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial
data.abstract: Supplemental Digital Content is Available in the Text. The use of phantom motor execution and phantom motor imagery aided by extended reality substantially alleviates phantom limb pain and its associated comorbidities. Abstract Phantom limb pain (PLP) represents a significant challenge after amputation. This study investigated the use of phantom motor execution (PME) and phantom motor imagery (PMI) facilitated by extended reality (XR) for the treatment of PLP. Both treatments used XR, but PME involved overt execution of phantom movements, relying on the decoding of motor intent using machine learning to enable real-time control in XR. In contrast, PMI involved mental rehearsal of phantom movements guided by XR. The study hypothesized that PME would be superior to PMI. A multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial was conducted in 9 outpatient clinics across 7 countries. Eighty-one participants with PLP were randomly assigned to PME or PMI training. The primary outcome was the change in PLP, measured by the Pain Rating Index, from baseline to treatment cessation. Secondary outcomes included various aspects related to PLP, such as the rate of clinically meaningful reduction in pain (CMRP; >50% pain decrease). No evidence was found for superiority of overt execution (PME) over imagery (PMI) using XR. PLP decreased by 64.5% and 68.2% in PME and PMI groups, respectively. Thirty-seven PME participants (71%) and 19 PMI participants (68%) experienced CMRP. Positive changes were recorded in all other outcomes, without group differences. Pain reduction for PME was larger than previously reported. Despite our initial hypothesis not being confirmed, PME and PMI, aided by XR, are likely to offer meaningful PLP relief to most patients. These findings merit consideration of these therapies as viable treatment options and alternatives to pharmacological treatments.

consensus_result.Title: Extended reality used in the treatment of phantom limb pain: a multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial
consensus_result.Abstract: Phantom limb pain (PLP) represents a significant challenge after amputation. This study investigated the use of phantom motor execution (PME) and phantom motor imagery (PMI) facilitated by extended reality (XR) for the treatment of PLP. Both treatments used XR, but PME involved overt execution of phantom movements, relying on the decoding of motor intent using machine learning to enable real-time control in XR. A multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial was conducted in 9 outpatient clinics across 7 countries. Eighty-one participants with PLP were randomly assigned to PME or PMI training. No evidence was found for superiority of overt execution (PME) over imagery (PMI) using XR. PLP decreased by 64.5% and 68.2% in PME and PMI groups, respectively. These findings merit consideration for clinical implementation.

confidence_factors.reasoning: Vision data used as foundation with strong API validation from multiple sources (Crossref, Europe PMC, PubMed, Semantic Scholar). Key enhancements include PMID/PMCID from Europe PMC, citation count from Semantic Scholar, and open access status from Unpaywall. All API data was cross-validated for coherence with vision data.

api_success_summary.insights: Strong coherence among major scholarly APIs (Crossref, Europe PMC, PubMed, Semantic Scholar). Europe PMC provided the most comprehensive enhancements including affiliations and funding information. DOAJ failed due to missing DOI, while arXiv had no matches. DataCite and CORE returned supplementary materials rather than the main article.

llm_topics_json.prompt_sent:
You are a scientific research assistant extracting data for academic comparison tables with statistical rigor.

CRITICAL INSTRUCTIONS FOR ACADEMIC COMPARISON:

- SYSTEMATICALLY scan ALL content: text, tables, figures, charts, appendices
- PRIORITIZE quantitative data while preserving qualitative context
- When conflicts exist in the paper, prioritize MOST RECENT/AUTHORITATIVE source
- Extract ALL relevant details mentioned - DON'T truncate important information
- Include statistical tests results (Z-scores, t-values, chi-square, etc.)
- Extract accuracy rates, completion rates, success rates with specific numbers
- Capture comparative data (e.g., "46% vs 27%", "Group A: 64.5%, Group B: 68.2%")
- Use proper numeric format: "p = 0.007" not "p = .007", "81" not "eighty-one"

COMPREHENSIVE CAPTURE REQUIREMENTS:

- List ALL hardware components: cameras, sensors, headsets, controllers, phones, tablets, webcams, probes
- Include ALL software details: platforms, SDKs, libraries, export formats (CSV, JSON), feedback systems
- Capture ALL measurement instruments: scales, questionnaires, assessment tools (SUS, NASA-TLX, FES-I, MoCA, IKDC, VAS, ABC scale, WHODAS 2.0, etc.)
- Note ALL technical specifications: resolutions, frame rates, tracking capabilities, joint counts
- Include ALL study phases: pilot tests, technical validation, user studies, expert evaluations
- Capture ALL procedural details: training time, calibration steps, data export processes, real-time feedback

CONFLICT RESOLUTION:

- If conflicting information exists, prioritize methods/results over abstract
- When uncertain, include both: "X in abstract, Y in methods section"

Extract the following 7 scientific topics:

1. *study_design*: Extract the PRIMARY study type/design using the most specific and authoritative terminology from the paper's methods section. Recognize equivalent terms: "RCT" = "Randomized controlled trial", "Pilot study" = "Feasibility pilot study", "Cross-sectional" = "Observational cross-sectional", "User study" = "User evaluation study". When multiple study type descriptions exist, prioritize the most comprehensive version from methods over abstract. Include specific qualifiers when mentioned (e.g., "multicenter", "double-blind", "waitlist-controlled") as these add valuable detail. Format as brief phrase describing core study methodology, avoiding generic terms like "study" or "research" alone.

2. *methodology*: ONE comprehensive sentence covering: technology + application + key technical details. Include: ALL device models, software platforms, measurement tools, statistical analyses. Capture ALL hardware components mentioned (cameras, sensors, controllers, probes, etc.). Include ALL software features (real-time feedback, data export, tracking capabilities). Mention ALL technical specifications (joint tracking numbers, frame rates, resolutions). Example: "Microsoft HoloLens 2 with HoloAnatomy platform for 3D anatomical procedural visualization using real-time motion tracking of 25 joints with CSV data export and real-time visual feedback".

3. *sample_size*: Format: "X participants/patients" (use paper's exact terminology). Include TOTAL numbers if multiple groups exist. Include ALL test phases: technical tests, pilot studies, user evaluations. Example: "25 total: 23 biomedical students + 2 clinical experts; 50 technical validation readings".

4. *population*: ALL demographic details and characteristics not captured in sample_size. Include age, profession, condition, experience, setting details. Add specific numbers when available. Include recruitment sources and inclusion/exclusion criteria.

5. *primary_outcome*: Include ALL measurement tools, scales, timing, specific metrics, usability criteria (ease of use, realism, anatomical accuracy). List ALL assessment instruments used and functional scales (SUS, NASA-TLX, FES-I, MoCA, IKDC, VAS, ABC scale, WHODAS 2.0, etc.), and evaluation dimensions beyond the primary measures.. Include ALL comparison conditions and timepoints. Example: "Patient understanding via 5-point Likert scale assessed pre/post intervention, plus SUS usability scores and NASA-TLX workload assessment".

6. *key_findings*: PRIORITIZE statistical results with practical implications. Format: "Finding 1: [statistical data + meaning]. Finding 2: [data + context]". Include ALL significant findings, p-values, effect sizes, accuracy rates, comparative data, accuracy measurements (sub-mm, degrees), specific understanding domains (surgical risks, operative steps, recovery), and detailed performance metrics beyond statistical significance. Present ALL questionnaire results, prototype performance, qualitative benefits. Include ALL cost factors, training requirements, implementation details. Capture ALL comparison groups and their specific results. Be comprehensive - capture complete findings picture. Include ALL technical specifications mentioned: accuracy measurements (sub-mm, degrees).

7. *limitations*: Extract ALL limitations from limitation/discussion sections. Include sample size issues, technical equipment requirements, methodological, practical constraints. Mention ALL equipment needs, calibration requirements, manufacturing variability. Include ALL generalizability issues, validity concerns, implementation barriers. Capture training requirements, cost constraints, specialized equipment needs. Note real-world applicability issues and clinical implementation challenges. Don't summarize - capture complete limitation landscape.

Return as valid JSON with this EXACT structure:

{
  "study_design": "string",
  "methodology": "string",
  "sample_size": "string",
  "population": "string",
  "primary_outcome": "string",
  "key_findings": "string",
  "limitations": "string"
}

extracted_topics.population: Participants aged 58.18 years on average, with chronic phantom limb pain (PLP) persisting beyond 3 months, recruited from 9 outpatient clinics across 7 countries.
extracted_topics.limitations: Higher than anticipated dropout rate, potential influence of contextual factors, and the need for specialized equipment and training for XR interventions.
extracted_topics.methodology: Extended reality (XR) using Microsoft HoloLens for phantom motor execution (PME) and phantom motor imagery (PMI) with real-time motion tracking, myoelectric signal decoding, and real-time feedback in virtual environments.
extracted_topics.sample_size: 81 participants: 53 allocated to PME, 28 to PMI
extracted_topics.key_findings: Finding 1: No significant difference between PME and PMI in PRI change (p = 0.75 ± 0.12). Finding 2: Both groups showed improvements in secondary outcomes like PLP Weighted Pain Distribution (WPD) and PLP Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) with reductions at various time points.
extracted_topics.primary_outcome: Change in PLP intensity measured by the Pain Rating Index (PRI) from the Short-Form McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ) between baseline and end of treatment.
